justify;">(k) “Seed Analyst” means a Seed Analyst appointed under section 12;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3[ (kk) “Seed Dealer” means a person or a company or an organization involved in production of seeds or carrying on the business of importing, selling, hoarding for sale, bartering or otherwise supplying any seed of any kind or variety for agricultural purpose:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, farmer producing or hoarding seeds partly for his own use and partly for sale in the local hats and bazars by himself or through any other person, in small quantities shall not be treated as Seed Dealer.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l) “Seed Inspector” means a Seed Inspector appointed under section 13;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m) “Seed Laboratory” means the Government Seed Laboratory established or, as the case may be, declared under section 4; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n) “variety” means a sub-division of a kind identifiable by growth, yields, plant, fruit, seed or other characteristics.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>National Seed Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) The Government shall, as soon as may be after the commencement of this Ordinance, constitute a Board to be called the National Seed Board to advise the Government on matters arising out of the administration of this Ordinance and to carry out the other functions assigned to it by or under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"> (2) The Board shall consist of the following members, namely-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) Secretary, Ministry of Agriculture, who shall also be the Chairman of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) Vice Chancellor, Bangladesh Agricultural University (BAU), Mymensingh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) Executive Chairman, Bangladesh Agricultural Research Council (BARC), Dhaka;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) Chairman, Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation (BADC), Dhaka;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) Director General, Department of Agricultural Extension (DAE), Dhaka;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) Director General, Bangladesh Rice Research Institute (BRRI), Gazipur;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) Director General, Bangladesh Agricultural Research Institute (BARI), Dhaka;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) Director General, Bangladesh Jute Research Institute (BJRI), Dhaka;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) Director General, Bangladesh Institute of Nuclear Agriculture (BINA), Mymensingh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) Director General, Bangladesh Sugarcane Research Institute (BSRI), Pabna;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k) Executive Director, Cotton Development Board, Dhaka;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l) Member Director (Seed), Bangladesh Agriculture Development Corporation (BADC), Dhaka;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m) Director, Seed Certification Agency (SCA), Gazipur;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n) Director, Soil Resource Development Institute (SRDI);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(o) Director, Plant Protection Wing, Department of Agricultural Extension (DAE);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(p) a representative of the Ministry of Finance (Finance Division), not below the rank of Joint Secretary;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(q) a representative of the Private Seed Dealers and Merchants Association;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(r) a representative of the Private Seed Growers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(s) a representative from the farmer's community; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(t) Director General (Seed), Ministry of Agriculture, Dhaka-Member Secretary.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) [Omitted by section 3 of the Seeds (Amendment) Act, 2005 (Act No. XXVI of 2005).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Government shall provide the Board with such clerical and other staff as it may consider necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Government shall, by notification in the official Gazette, publish the 5[ names and designations] of all the members of the Board and thereupon the Board shall be deemed to be constituted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) Omitted by section 3 of the Seeds (Amendment) Act, 1997 (Act No. XIII of 1997).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6[ (7) The Government may, at any time, terminate the appointment of a member of the Board without assigning any reason. The tenure of the members of the Board representing Private Seed Dealers and Merchants, Private Seed Growers, and Farmer's Community shall be for a period of three years.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(8) When a member of the Board dies, resigns or otherwise ceases to be a member, the vacancy shall be filled by fresh appointment</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(9) No person shall be, or shall continue to be, a member who-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) is or at any time has been convicted an offence which, in the opinion of the Government, is an offence involving moral turpitude; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) is of unsound mind and stands so adjudged by a competent Court; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) is or has at any time been adjudged insolvent; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) absents himself from three consecutive meetings of the Board without leave of absence from the Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(10) The Board may appoint one or more committees consisting wholly of members of the Board or wholly of other persons or partly of members of the Board and partly of other persons, as it thinks fit, for the purpose of discharging such of its functions as may be delegated to such committee or committees by the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(11) The Board may, subject to the previous approval of the Government, make by-laws for regulating its own procedure and the procedure of a committee appointed by it under sub-section (10) and the conduct of all business to be transacted by it or a committee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(12) No act or proceeding of the Board shall be invalid merely on the ground of the existence of any vacancy in, or any defect in the constitution of, the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Government Seed Laboratory</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. The Government may 8[ establish Seed Laboratory] to be called the Government Seed Laboratory or declare, by notification in the official Gazette, any Seed Laboratory as the Government Seed Laboratory for the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to specify kinds or varieties of seeds</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9[ 5. (1) The Government shall regulate the quality of seed of any kind or variety to be sold and used for the purposes of agriculture. If the Government after consultation with the Board is of opinion that it is necessary or expedient to regulate sale, distribution, bartering or otherwise supplying, and import of seed of any kind or variety, it may, by notification in the Official Gazette, specify such kind or variety to be a notified kind or variety for the purposes of this Ordinance and different kinds or varieties may be notified for different areas.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) New varieties of non-notified crops developed by public or private agencies will be subject to approval and certification by the Board before being released.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) New varieties of notified crops developed by public agencies will be subject to approval by, and be registered with the Board before being released.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Varieties of non-notified crops those are imported or locally developed by a private agency shall be registered with the Board giving prescribed cultivar description.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) In the event of a seed of any kind or variety is found to be harmful or potentially harmful to agriculture in any way, the Board may prohibit the sale, distribution, bartering, or otherwise supplying, import and use of that variety and may take any other action in the interest of agriculture.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) Any proposal for release of new varieties of notified crops shall be examined by a Technical Committee headed by the Executive Vice-Chairman. Bangladesh Agricultural Research Council (BARC), and consisting of representatives of National Agricultural Research System (NARS). Seed Certification Agency, Department of Agricultural Extension (DAE), Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation (BADC), private sector Seed Growers and Farmers Associations and make recommendation to the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(7) Proposal for release of new varieties of non-notified crops developed by any public agency shall be subject to examination by the Technical Committee formed under sub-section (6).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to specify the standards of seed quality</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"> 6. After consultation with the Board, the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, specify-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the standard regarding the germination percentage, purity percentage, moisture content and such other components of seed quality with respect to any seed of 11[ any kind or variety];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the mark or label to indicate that such seed conforms to the standard specified under clause (a) and the particulars which such mark or label may contain.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Regulation of sale of seeds of notified kinds or varieties</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"> 7. No Seed Dealer shall carry on the business of selling, keeping for sale, offering to sell, bartering or otherwise supplying any seed of any notified kind or variety, unless-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13[ (a) such kind or variety of seed is registered with the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"> (aa) for the purpose of this Ordinance every Seed Dealer shall be registered with the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) such seed is identifiable as its kind or variety;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) such seed conforms to the standards of seed quality and the container of such seed bears, in the prescribed manner, the mark or label containing the correct particulars thereof specified under clauses (a) and (b) of section 6;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) he complies with such other requirements as may be prescribed.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Labeling of Seeds</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"> 7A. Seed packaging in containers shall have a label containing batch identification, net weight or count, minimum germination percentage, physical purity, name and address of the company packaging the seed, and the date of packaging.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Seed Certification Agency</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) The Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, establish a Certification Agency to be called the Seed Certification Agency (SCA) to carry out the functions entrusted to it by or under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The functions of SCA shall among other things include:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to advise seed producers on production, processing and quality control of seeds;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to carry out post market quality control through inspection, testing;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to collect data or information on seed production, processing and quality control for use by the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) to certify all Breeder and Foundation seed of controlled crops;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) to certify seeds for seed enterprises as a service, if resources permit;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) to co-ordinate the variety evaluation and release mechanism for notified crops;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) to advise NSB on the de-notification of varieties for reasons of poor performance or disease and pest susceptibility;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) to help DAE in the promotion and use of improved seed of HYV's among farmers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) to collect samples of truthfully labeled seeds throughout the country and check their declared standards through appropriate tests; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) to enforce the provisions of the Seed Ordinance, 1977 and take appropriate legal measures against the offenders.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Grant of certificate by the Certification Agency</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) Any person selling, keeping for sale, offering to sell, bartering or otherwise supplying any seed of 17[ any kind or variety] may, if he desires to have such seed certified by the Certification Agency, apply to the Certification Agency for grant of a certificate for the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every application under sub-section (1) shall be made in such form, shall contain such particulars and shall be accompanied by such fees as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) On receipt of any such application for the grant of a certificate, the Certification Agency may, after such enquiry as it thinks fit and after satisfying itself that the seed to which the application relates conforms at least to the minimum limits of germination and purity specified for that seed under clause (a) of section 6, grant a certificate in such form and on such conditions as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Revocation of certificate</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. If the Certification Agency is satisfied, either on a reference made to it in this behalf or otherwise, that-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the certificate granted by it under section 9 has been obtained by misrepresentation as to any essential fact, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the holder of the certificate has, without reasonable cause, failed to comply with the conditions subject to which the certificate has been granted or has contravened any of the provisions of this Ordinance or the rules made thereunder,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">then, without prejudice to any other penalty to which the holder of the certificate may be liable under this Ordinance, the Certification Agency may, after giving the holder of the certificate an opportunity of showing cause, revoke the certificate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Appeal</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Certification Agency under section 9 or section 10 may, within thirty days from the date on which the decision is communicated to him and on payment of such fees as may be prescribed, prefer an appeal to such authority as may be specified by the Government in this behalf:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the appellate authority may entertain an appeal after the expiry of the said period of thirty days if it is satisfied that the appellant was prevented by sufficient cause from filing the appeal in time.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) On receipt of an appeal under sub-section (1), the appellate authority shall, after giving the appellant an opportunity of being heard, dispose of the appeal as expeditiously as possible.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Every order of the appellate authority under this section shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Seed Analyst</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint such persons as it thinks fit, having the prescribed qualifications, to be Seed Analyst and define the areas within which they shall exercise jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Seed Inspectors</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint such persons as it thinks fit, having the prescribed qualifications, to be Seed Inspectors and define the areas within which they shall exercise jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every Seed Inspector shall be deemed to be a public servant within the meaning of section 21 of the Penal Code (Act XLV of 1860) and shall be officially subordinate to such authority as the Government may specify in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Powers of Seed Inspectors</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) The Seed Inspector may-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) take samples of any seed of 18[ any kind or variety] from-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) any person selling such seed; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) any person who is, in the course of conveying, delivering or preparing to deliver such seed to a purchaser or a consignee; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii) a purchaser or a consignee after delivery of such seed to him;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) send such sample for analysis to the Seed Analyst for the area within which such sample has been taken;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) exercise such other powers as may be necessary for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance or any rule made thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Where any sample of any seed of 19[ any kind or variety] is taken under clause (a) of sub-section (1), its cost, calculated at the rate at which such seed is usually sold to the public, shall be paid on demand to the person from whom it is taken.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The power conferred by this section includes power to break open any container in which any seed of 20[ any kind or variety] may be contained or to break open the door of any premises where any such seed may be kept for sale:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the power to break open the door shall be exercised only after the owner or any other person in occupation of the premises, if he is present therein, refuses to open the door on being called open to do so.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Where the Seed Inspector takes any 21[ action] under clause (a) of sub-section (1), he shall, as far as possible, call not less than two persons to be present at the time when such action is taken and take their signatures on a memorandum to be prepared in the prescribed form and manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act V of 1898) shall, so far as may be, apply to any search or seizure made this section as they apply to any search or seizure made under the authority of a warrant issued under section 98 of the said Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Procedure to be followed by Seed Inspectors</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. (1) Whenever a Seed Inspector intends to take sample of any seed of 22[ any kind or variety] for analysis, he shall-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) give notice in writing, then and there, of such intention to the person from whom he intends to take sample;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) except in special cases provided by rules made under this Ordinance, take three-representative samples in the prescribed manner and mark and seal or fasten up each sample in such manner as its nature permits.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) When samples of any seed of 23[ any kind or variety] are taken under sub-section (1), the Seed Inspector shall-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) deliver one sample to the person from whom it has been taken;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) send in the prescribed manner another sample for analysis to the Seed Analyst for the area within which such sample has been taken; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) retain the remaining sample in the prescribed manner for production in case any legal proceedings are taken or for analysis by the Seed Laboratory under sub-section (2) of section 16, as the case may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) If the person from whom the samples have been taken refuses to accept one of the samples, the Seed Inspector shall send intimation to the Seed Analyst of such refusal and thereupon the Seed Analyst receiving the sample for analysis shall divide it into two parts and shall seal or fasten up one of those parts and shall cause it, either upon receipt of the sample or when he delivers his report, to be delivered to the Seed Inspector who shall retain it for production in case legal proceedings are taken.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Where a Seed Inspector takes any action under clause (c) of sub-section (1) of section 14-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) he shall use all despatch in ascertaining whether or not the seed contravenes any of the provisions of section 7 and if it is ascertained that the seed does not so contravene, forthwith revoke the order passed under the said clause or, as the case may be, take such action as may be necessary for the return of the stock of the seed seized;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) if he seized the stock of the seed, he shall, as soon as may be, inform a Magistrate and take his orders as to the custody thereof;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) without prejudice to the institution of any prosecution, if the alleged offence is such that the defect may be removed by the possessor of the seed, he shall, on being satisfied that the defect has been so removed, forthwith revoke the order passed, any record, register, document or any other material object under clause (d) of sub-section (1) of section 14, he shall, as soon as may be, inform a Magistrate and take his orders as to the custody thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Report of Seed Analyst</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. (1) The Seed Analyst shall, as soon as may be, after the receipt of the sample under sub-section (2) of section 15, analyse the sample at the Seed Laboratory and deliver, in such form as may be prescribed, one copy of the report of result of the analysis to the Seed Inspector and another copy thereof to the person from whom the sample has been taken.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) After the institution of a prosecution under this Ordinance, the accused may, on payment of the prescribed fee, make an application to the Court for sending any of the samples mentioned in clause (a) or clause (c) of sub-section (2) of section 15 to the Seed Laboratory for its report and on receipt of the application, the Court shall first ascertain that the mark and the seal or fastening as provided in clause (b) of sub-section (1) of section 15 are intact and may then despatch the sample under its own seal to the Seed Laboratory which shall thereupon send its report to the Court in the prescribed form within one month from the date of receipt of the sample, specifying the result of the analysis.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The report sent by the Seed Laboratory under sub-section (2), shall supersede the report given by the Seed Analyst under sub-section (1).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Where the report sent by the Seed Laboratory is produced in any proceedings, it shall not be necessary to produce in such proceedings any sample or part thereof taken for analysis.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Import and Export of Seeds</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">24[ 17. (1) No person shall export or import or cause to be exported or imported any seed of any kind or variety unless it conforms to the standards of seeds quality, and the container of such seeds bears, in the prescribed manner, the mark or label containing the correct particulars thereof specified for that seed under section 6.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Seeds of approved varieties of all notified crops may be imported for commercial sale. Registered seed growers may be permitted to import small quantities of such varieties not approved by NSB for the purpose of research and adaptability testing.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) There shall be no restriction on import of seeds of non-notified crops, except for ensuring prescribed quality.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) All imported seeds shall be subject to the provisions of the Destructive Inspects and Pests Act, 1914 (Act No. II of 1914).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Recognition of seed certification agencies of foreign countries</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. On the recommendation of the Board, the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, recognise any seed certification agency established in any foreign country 25[ for the purposes] of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Cognizance of Offences</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">26[ 19. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act No. V of 1898), no court shall take cognizance of any offence punishable under this Ordinance except upon a complaint in writing, made by a Seed Inspector.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Place and Procedure of trial</p><p style="text-align: justify;">27[ 19A. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act No. V of 1898) an offence punishable under this Ordinance may be tried at any place within the local jurisdiction of the metropolitan magistrate or of the magistrate of the first class.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19B. If any person contravenes any provision of this Ordinance or any rule made there under, or prevents a Seed Inspector from taking sample under this Ordinance or prevents him from exercising any other power conferred upon him by or under this Ordinance, he shall, on conviction, be punishable-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) for the first offence, with imprisonment for a term no exceeding thirty days or with fine which may extend to taka five thousand, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) in the event such person having been previously convicted of any offence under this section, with imprisonment for a term not exceeding ninety days or with fine which may extend to taka twenty thousand.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Special Provision regarding fines</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19C. Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 32 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act No. V of 1898), it shall be lawful for any metropolitan magistrate or magistrate of the first class to pass a sentence of fine under this Ordinance exceeding ten thousand taka.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Forfeiture of property</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. When any person has been convicted under this Ordinance for the contravention of any of the provisions of this Ordinance or the rules made thereunder, the seed in respect of which the contravention has been committed may, if the Court so orders, be forfeited to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Offence by companies</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. (1) Where an offence under this Ordinance has been committed by a company, every person who at the time the offence was committed was in charge of, and was responsible to, the company for the conduct of the business of the company as well as the company shall be deemed to be guilty of the offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that nothing contained in this sub-section shall render any such person liable to any punishment under this Ordinance if he proves that the offence was committed without his knowledge or that he exercised all due diligence to prevent the commission of such offence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), where an offence under this Ordinance has been committed by a company and it is proved that the offence has been committed with the consent or connivance of, or is attributable to any neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other officer of the company, such director, manager, secretary or other officer shall also be deemed to be guilty of that offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation</strong>.-For the purposes of this section,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “company” means any body corporate and includes a firm or other association of individuals; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “director”, in relation to a firm, means partner in the firm.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Protection of action taken in good faith</p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against the Government or any officer of the Government for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make rules</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules to carry out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular, and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the functions of the Board and the travelling and daily allowances payable to members of the Board and of the committee;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the functions of the Seed Laboratory;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the functions of the Certification Agency;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the manner of marking or labelling the container of seed of any notified kind or variety;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the requirements which may be complied with by a person carrying on the business referred to in section 7;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) the form of application for the grant of a certificate under section 9, the particulars it may contain, the fees which shall accompany it, the form of the certificate and the conditions subject to which the certificate may be granted;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) the form and manner in which and the fee on payment of which an appeal may be preferred under section 11 and the procedure to be followed by the appellate authority in disposing of the appeal;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) the qualifications and duties of Seed Analysts and Seed Inspectors;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) the manner in which samples may be taken by the Seed Inspectors, the procedure for sending such samples to the Seed Analysts or the Seed Laboratory and the manner of analysing such samples;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) the form of report of the result of the analysis, and the fees payable in respect of such report;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k) the records to be maintained by a person carrying on the business referred to in section 7 and the particulars which such records shall contain; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l) any other matter which is to be or may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Clause (hh) was inserted by section 2 of the Seeds (Amendment) Act, 2005 (Act No. XXVI of 2005)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 Clause (j) was substituted by section 2 of the Seeds (Amendment) Act, 1997 (Act No. XIII of 1997)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 Clause (kk) was substituted by section 2 of the Seeds (Amendment) Act, 2005 (Act No. XXVI of 2005)</p><p style="text-align: 596	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE STATUTORY CORPORATIONS (DELEGATION OF POWERS) (REPEAL) ORDINANCE, 1976 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE STATUTORY CORPORATIONS (DELEGATION OF POWERS) (REPEAL) ORDINANCE, 1976 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XVI OF 1976).[10th March, 1976]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to repeal the Statutory Corporations (Delegation of Powers) Ordinance, 1975.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to repeal the Statutory Corporations (Delegation of Powers) Ordinance, 1975 (XXXVIII of 1975);</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamations of the 20th August, 1975, and the 8th November, 1975, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> Short Title </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Statutory Corporations (Delegation of Powers) (Repeal) Ordinance, 1976.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Repeal of Ordinance XXXVIII of 1975</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The Statutory Corporations (Delegation of Powers) Ordinance, 1975 (XXXVIII of 1975), is hereby repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
597	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE SUPREME COURT JUDGES (REMUNERATION AND PRIVILEGES) ORDINANCE, 1978 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE SUPREME COURT JUDGES (REMUNERATION AND PRIVILEGES) ORDINANCE, 1978 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XI OF 1978).[28th March, 1978]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for the remuneration and privileges of the Judges of the Supreme Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the remuneration and privileges of the Judges of the Supreme Court;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamations of the 20th August, 1975, and the 8th November, 1975, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) Ordinance, 1978.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> Definition </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context, “Judge” means a Judge of a Division of the Supreme Court, and includes the Chief Justice and an Additional Judge of a Division of that Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Salary</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. 1[ (1) There shall be paid to the Judges salary at the following rates, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) The Chief Justice - Taka 56,000 Per mensem;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) A Judge of the - Taka 53,100 Per mensem;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Appellate Division</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii) A Judge of the High - Taka 49,100 Per mensem;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Court Division</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No income-tax shall be payable in respect of 2[ salary and allowances payable to a Judge under this Ordinance].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3A[Omitted]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3A. [Omitted by section 3 of the Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1985 (Ordinance No. XLV of 1985).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3B[Omitted]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3B.[Omitted by section 3 of the Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 1992 (Act No. XIII of 1992).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3C[Omitted]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3C.[Omitted by section 3 of the Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 1992 (Act No. XIII of 1992).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3D[Omitted]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3[ ***]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Recreation allowance</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4[ 3E. (1) There shall be paid to a judge, a recreation allowance equal to one month's pay of his salary once in every three years for the purpose of taking leave for rest and recreation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The recreation allowance shall be paid in addition to the leave salary as mentioned in the section 7 of the Supreme Court Judges (Leave, Pension and Privileges) Ordinance, 1982 (Ordinance No. XX of 1982).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Privileges regarding residence, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. 5[ (1)]A Judge shall be entitled to, and provided with,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        a furnished residence free from the payment of any rent and charges on account of municipal taxes and local rate and of the use of electricity, water and gas and, until such residence is provided, a Judge shall be paid a residence allowance of 6[ Taka 26,600] per mensem;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7[ (b)   an official transport on the same terms as are admissible to a Secretary to the Government and, until such transport is provided or if it is not required by him, he shall be paid a car allowance of 8[ Taka 15,000] per mensem if he uses his own car or Taka 1,000 per mensem if he does not use his own car; and]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        a telephone at his residence at Government expense.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9[ (2) There shall be paid to the Judges a domestic aid allowance at the following rates, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) The Chief Justice - Taka 1625 Per mensem;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) A Judge of the - Taka 1465 Per mensem;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Appellate Division</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii) A Judge of the High - Taka 1300 Per mensem.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Court Division</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10[ (3) There shall be paid to the Judges a sumptuary allowance at the following rates, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) The Chief Justice - Taka 7000 Per mensem;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) A Judge of the - Taka 5000 Per mensem;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Appellate Division</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii) A Judge of the High - Taka 3000 Per mensem.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Court Division</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Medical facilities</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. A Judge and the members of his family shall be entitled to medical facilities admissible under the Special Medical Attendance Rules, except that he and the members of his family shall be entitled to medical treatment at the residence of the Judge; and such medical facilities shall continue to be admissible after the Judge has retired or otherwise ceased to hold office.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Rights relating to leave, pension, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) In respect of leave, pension, gratuity and provident fund, a Judge shall be entitled, subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, to all the rights, privileges and allowances as were admissible to him immediately before the commencement of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) [Omitted by section 4 of the Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 2005 (Act No. XXV of 2005).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Option of Judges</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. This Ordinance shall not apply to a Judge who, immediately before the commencement of this Ordinance, was holding office as a Judge of the 11[ High Court Division] or 12[ Appellate Division of the Supreme Court] and who, within a period of three months from such commencement, exercises in writing communicated to the Accountant General of Bangladesh his option to be governed by the provisions of law which, immediately before such commencement, were applicable to him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Repeal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. The Supreme Court and the High Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) Ordinance, 1976 (LXV of 1976) is hereby repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Retrospective effect</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. The provisions of this Ordinance shall be deemed to have taken effect on the 1st day of December, 1977.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Sub-section (1) was substituted for sub-section (1) by section 2 of The Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 2010 (Act No. XXII of 2010) (with effect from 1st July, 2009).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words “salary and allowances payable to a Judge under this Ordinance” were substituted for the words, brackets and figure “salary payable to a Judge under sub-section (1)” by section 2 of the Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Second Amendment) Act, 1990 (Act No. XLI of 1990)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 Section 3D was omitted by section 3 of The Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 2010 (Act No. XXII of 2010) (With effect from 1st July, 2009).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 Section 3E was inserted by section 3 of The Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 2009 (Act No. LIV of 2009).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The existing provision was numbered as sub-section (1) of that section by section 4 of the Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 1992 (Act No. XIII of 1992)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 The figure and comma “Taka 26,600” was substituted for The figure and comma “Taka 20,000” by section 4(a) of The Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 2010 (Act No. XXII of 2010) (With effect from 1st July, 2009).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 Clause (b) was substituted by section 2 of the Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1983 (Ordinance No. LIX of 1983)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 The figure and comma “Taka 15,000” was substituted for the figure and comma “Taka 12,000” by section 4(a) of The Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 2010 (Act No. XXII of 2010) (with effect from 1st July, 2010).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9 Sub-section (2) was substituted for sub-section (2) by section 4(b) of The Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 2010 (Act No. XXII of 2010) (with effect from 1st July, 2010).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10 Sub-section (3) was substituted for sub-section (3) by section 4(c) of The Supreme Court Judges (Remuneration and Privileges) (Amendment) Act, 2010 (Act No. XXII of 2010) (With effect from 1st July, 2009).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11 The words “High Court Division” were substituted for the words “High Court” by Article 7(1)(a) of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972) as amended by the Bangladesh Adaptation of Existing Laws (Amendment) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 150 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12 The words “Appellate Division of the Supreme Court” were substituted for the words “Supreme Court” by Article 7(1)(b) of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972) as amended by the Bangladesh Adaptation of Existing Laws (Amendment) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 150 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source :  Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
598	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE SUPREME COURT JUDGES (TRAVELLING ALLOWANCES) ORDINANCE, 1976 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE SUPREME COURT JUDGES (TRAVELLING ALLOWANCES) ORDINANCE, 1976 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XXX OF 1976).[14th May, 1976]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to determine travelling allowances payable to the Judges of the Supreme Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to determine travelling allowances payable to the Judges of the Supreme Court and for matters connected therewith;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the proclamations of the 20th August, 1975 and the 8th November, 1975 and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> Short title </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Supreme Court Judges (Travelling Allowances) Ordinance, 1976.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> Definition </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context, “Judge” means a Judge of a Division of the Supreme Court, and includes the Chief Justice and an Additional Judge of such Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel on duty</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Travelling allowances of a Judge travelling on duty in Bangladesh shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of sections 4 to 9.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Explanation.- The expression “travelling on duty” shall include travels within Bangladesh during vacation of a Judge, not being a vacation Judge,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) for doing duty during vacation in the Supreme Court;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) for performing the functions of the office or post to which he may be appointed during his period of service as Judge; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) for returning after doing such duty or performing such functions to the place from where the journey was undertaken for the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel by railway</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. When travelling by railway, a Judge shall be entitled to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1)        (a)        a first class two-berth compartment or a coupe-compartment in an air-conditioned coach reserved on High Official Requisition, without payment of any fare for himself; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the reimbursement of one first class fare, including air-condition surcharge, if any, he pays for himself;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        the reimbursement of fare for two servants, if actually paid, at the lowest class rate; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3)        the reimbursement of the expenses actually incurred in carrying luggage, not exceeding 1[ one hundred and twelve kilograms], exclusive of free allowance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel by steamer</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. When travelling by steamer, a Judge shall be entitled to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1)        (a)        a first class cabin reserved on High Official Requisition, without payment of any fare for himself; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the reimbursement of one first class fare he actually pays for himself;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) the reimbursement of fare for two servants, if actually paid, at the lowest class rate, subject to usual deductions on account of messing charges, if any; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3)        the reimbursement of the expenses actually incurred in carrying luggage, not exceeding 2[ one hundred and twelve kilograms], exclusive of free allowance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel by railway or steamer in reserved accommodation</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. Any person (other than the servants) travelling with a Judge in reserved accommodation allowed under sections 4 and 5 shall pay the usual fare by purchase of first class ticket.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel by road</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. When travelling by road, a Judge shall be entitled to mileage allowance at the rate of 3[ taka one per kilometre].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel by air</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) When travelling by air, a Judge shall be entitled to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the reimbursement of one air fare actually paid by him;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the reimbursement of the actual cost of transporting luggage up to 4[ forty-five kilograms] inclusive of free luggage allowance admissible on a ticket; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the reimbursement of fare for two servants by rail, steamer or bus, if actually paid, at the lowest class rate, subject to usual deductions on account of messing charges, if any.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In the case of return journey by scheduled flights, a Judge should purchase a return ticket, if this involves a saving.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) In the case of air journey performed as a part of, or as a link in, a journey, a Judge shall be entitled to the same privileges in respect of servants and luggage as he is entitled to in the case of a railway journey.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The following certificate of the Judge should be appended to every travelling allowance bill for his travels involving air journey:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">“I certify that I have actually paid the amount of this bill and that it does not include any charge for the freight of any stores or goods, other than personal luggage, or any charge for refreshments, hotels or staging bungalows, other than what is included on that account in air fare itself.”</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Transport of Conveyance</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) A Judge shall be entitled to recover the actual cost incurred by him for transport, by closed railway van or steamer, at owner's risk, of his own car, including the fare at the lowest class rate for one driver or cleaner for the car.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A Judge may hire a taxi for journeys performed on duty at the place of halt while on tour and may recover, in lieu of costs allowed under sub-section (1) the expenditure actually incurred by him on the taxi hire:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the total amount recoverable for hire charges shall not exceed the cost of transporting his own car from his headquarters to the place of halt.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Daily Allowance</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5[ 10. A Judge shall be entitled to daily allowance at the rate of taka four hundred per diem in respect of any period of halt on duty including holidays, outside the headquarters of the Supreme Court.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel when not on duty</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. When proceeding on or returning from leave, or when returning to resume duty after vacation spent outside Bangladesh, or when returning to his place of residence after retirement, a Judge shall be entitled for journeys in Bangladesh,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        if he travels by railway or steamer, to a first class two-berth compartment or a coupe compartment in an air-conditioned coach, or a first class cabin, reserved on High Official Requisition, without payment of any fare for himself; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        if he travels by air, to the reimbursement of one air fare actually paid by him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel by a person being a Government servant to join post when appointed as Judge</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. (1) When a person already in Government service, on being appointed as a Judge, travels to join his post, he shall be deemed to be a Government servant on transfer and his travelling allowances shall be determined accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Such person may, at his option and in lieu of drawing travelling allowances under sub-section (1) claim the same privileges as are specified in section 13.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel by a person not being a Government servant to join post when appointed as Judge</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. When a person not already in Government service is appointed to be a Judge, he shall, when travelling to join his post, be entitled,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1)        if he travels by rail or steamer, to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) (i) a first class two-berth compartment or a coupe compartment in an air-conditioned coach, or a first class cabin, reserved on High Official Requisition, without payment of any fare for himself; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        the reimbursement of the actual first class fare including air condition surcharge, if any, he actually pays for himself; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the reimbursement of the first class fares, if actually paid, for his wife and children, including his step-children, ordinarily residing with him;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the reimbursement of the fares, if actually paid, for personal servants, not exceeding three in number, by road, rail or steamer, at the lowest class rate;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the reimbursement of the cost of carrying personal effects not exceeding 6[ two thousand two hundred fifty-nine kilograms] by road or by goods train or steamer at owner's risk; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the reimbursement of the cost of carrying his own motor car by passenger train or steamer at owner's risk;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        If he travels by air, he shall be entitled to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the reimbursement of his actual air fares at first class rate paid for himself, his wife and children, including step-children, ordinarily residing with him;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the reimbursement of the fares, if actually paid, for personal servants, not exceeding three in number, by road, rail or steamer, at the lowest class rate;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the reimbursement of the cost of carrying his own motor car by passenger train or steamer at owner's risk.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Joining time on transfer</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7[ 13A. (1) A Judge on transfer shall be entitled to a joining time to enable him to join the new post to which he is appointed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The period of joining time to which a Judge is entitled shall be determined as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        for preparation, six days; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        for the journey, one day for every twenty-four hours or fraction thereof spent in the journey.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3)        Notwithstanding anything contained in this section, the authority ordering posting of a Judge may, in any case, curtail or extend the period of joining time.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel on transfer</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13B. (1) Travelling allowances of a Judge travelling on transfer shall be determined in accordance with the following provisions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) When travelling by railway, a Judge shall be entitled to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        a first class two-berth compartment or coupe-compartment in an air-conditioned coach reserved on High Official Requisition without payment of any fare for himself, or the reimbursement of the fare, if any, he pays for himself;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) two extra fares of the highest class for himself; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the reimbursement of the fares of the highest class paid for the members of his family.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) When travelling by steamer, a Judge shall be entitled to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        a first class or air-conditioned two-berth cabin reserved on High Official Requisition, without payment of any fare for himself; or the reimbursement of the fare, if any, he pays for himself;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        two extra fares of the highest class for himself; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the reimbursement of the fares of the highest class paid for the members of his family.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) When travelling by road, a Judge shall be entitled to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the kilometre allowance at the rate of taka one per kilometre;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) one extra kilometre allowance for himself;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) one extra kilometre allowance if two members of his family accompany him and another extra kilometre allowance, if more than two such members accompany him; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the reimbursement of ferry charges paid for himself and the members of his family and for the car.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) When travelling by air, a Judge shall be entitled to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the reimbursement of the air fare paid for himself;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) one extra air fare for himself;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the reimbursement of the air fares paid for the members of his family; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the reimbursement of the embarkation fees paid for himself and the members of his family.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) A Judge on transfer shall be entitled to the reimbursement of fare for one servant, if paid, at the lowest class rate of the railway, steamer or bus by which the servant actually travelled.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(7) A Judge on transfer shall be entitled to the reimbursement of-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the expenses for carrying his own motor car, by closed railway van or steamer, at owner's risk;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the fare for one driver or cleaner for the car, if paid, at the lowest class rate of the railway, steamer or bus by which he actually travelled;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the expenses for carrying personal effects up to two thousand two hundred and fifty-nine kilograms by reserved boggie or luggage van in train or by steamer or by reserved truck; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the expenses for carrying personal effects up to fifty kilograms excluding the free baggage admissible on each ticket while travelling by air.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(8) A Judge on transfer shall be entitled to a sum of taka two hundred for packing and crating of his personal effects.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Explanation.- In this section, a Judge's family includes, provided they are residing with and wholly dependent upon him, his wife (but not more than one wife), his legitimate children and step children.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Travel by shortest route</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. When a journey can be performed by two or more routes, travelling allowance should be claimed by the shortest or the cheapest route.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Repeal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. The High Court Judges (Travelling Allowances) Order, 1965 (P.O. No. 4 of 1965), and the Supreme Court Judges (Travelling Allowances) Rules, 1958, are hereby repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The words “one hundred and twelve kilograms” were substituted for the words “three maunds” by section 2 of the Supreme Court Judges (Travelling Allowances) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. III of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words “one hundred and twelve kilograms” were substituted for the words “three maunds” by section 3 of the Supreme Court Judges (Travelling Allowances) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. III of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The words “taka one per kilometer” were substituted for the words “Taka one and paisa fifty per mile” by section 4 of the Supreme Court Judges (Travelling Allowances)(Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. III of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The words “forty-five kilograms” were substituted for the words “one hundred pounds” by section 5 of the Supreme Court Judges (Travelling Allowances) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. III of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 Section 10 was substituted by section 2 of the Supreme Court Judges (Travelling Allowances)(Amendment) Act, 2002 (Act No. V of 2002)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 The words “two thousand two hundred fifty-nine kilograms” were substituted for the words “sixty maunds” by section 7 of the Supreme Court Judges (Travelling Allowances)(Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. III of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 Sections 13A and 13B were inserted by section 8 of the Supreme Court Judges (Travelling Allowances)(Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. III of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
599	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE TEA ORDINANCE 1977</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE TEA ORDINANCE, 1977</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>(ORDINANCE NO. XXXVIII OF 1977)</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[29th July, 1977]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide measures for the expansion of export of tea, to establish new tea gardens and rehabilitate derelict tea gardens and generally for the promotion of the tea industry, and for levying a cess on tea produced in Bangladesh and to provide certain other matters ancillary thereto.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide measures for the expansion of export of tea, to establish new tea gardens and rehabilitate derelict tea gardens, and generally for the promotion of the tea industry, and for levying a cess on tea produced in Bangladesh and to provide certain other matters ancillary thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamations of the 20th August, 1975, and the 8th November, 1975, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Vice-President, acting as President under Article 55 of the Constitution, is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance :-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CHAPTER I</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>PRELIMINARY</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Tea Ordinance 1977.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “Board” means the Bangladesh Tea Board constituted under section 3;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “Collector” means-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) in relation to tea exported by sea, land or air, the Collector of Customs appointed under section 3 of the Customs Act, 1969 (IV of 1969), and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) in all other cases, the officer appointed by the Government to perform the duties of Collector under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) “Chairman” means the Chairman of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) “estate” means a tea estate and includes a tea garden or a part of tea estate or garden;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) “export” means to take out of Bangladesh by land, sea or air to any place outside Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) “member” means a member of the Board and includes the Chairman;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) “owner” includes any agent of an owner;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) “tea” means the commodity known as tea made from the leaves of the plant Camellia Thea or Camellia Sinnensis including adjacent tender stalks or green tea but excluding tea waste; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) “tea seed” includes seeds, roots, stumps, cuttings, buds and any living portion of the plant Camellia Thea or Camellia Sinnensis which may be used to propagate that plant.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CHAPTER II</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>BANGLADESH TEA BOARD</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Establishment of the Bangladesh Tea Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3.
